Notes: Ejecta includes lighter-toned region but not discrete light material.
Ejecta superposes seasonal frost and quickly shrank while frost remained. No convincing sign of ice in the first defrosted look.
No defrosted image until after winter passed; may have been modified.
Many craters; some have flat floors; slight color anomaly in largest.
Ring-shaped color anomaly. Never strong and not fully faded over four MY.
Relatively-blue crater wall became less distinct but seems to correlate with blast zone fading.
Crater with an anomalously bright illuminated wall but no convincing evidence for fading over time.
One 1.5-m crater has an anomalous relatively-blue crater wall. Classified as probable given the small size.

Multiple follow-on images show widespread bright patches throughout the image persisting through the summer. May be exposed ice. Candidate Impact looks somewhat distinct from these non-impact features but not considered definitive.
Slight relatively-blue glint within the crater. Bright spot not apparent in later image but blast pattern also erased.
Relatively-blue glint that later faded. Classified as probable because of small size and concurrent fading of blast zone.
Slight color anomaly. Later faded but not distinctive enough to raise above probable.
Some crater walls appear slightly bright. No follow-up image.
Initial image low quality but crater wall slightly bright. All subsequent images post-date seasonal cap.
Relatively-blue material. Fainter in follow-on image but blast zone also less distinct.
Weak relatively-blue color anomaly. Follow-on post-dates seasonal cap and planet-encircling dust storm.
Bright spot on sun-facing crater wall.
Relatively-blue patches approximately match location of dark spot in CTX but not considered definitive due to lack of well-defined crater.
Ejecta is bright but mostly relatively-yellow.
Slight color anomaly but feature has not faded significantly over five MY.
Some relatively-blue material, but only partially faded over three MY despite low latitude.
Crater walls slightly bright/blue but remain so after five MY.
Faint color anomaly which remains bright after five MY. Unlikely to be ice.
Impacted seasonal frost on south polar layered deposits. Small color feature in ESP_057574_0985 is likely ice. Irregular rim shape.
Ejecta relatively-yellow initially but blue/white later in fading and shrinking.
Slightly relatively-yellow but setting highly suggestive of ice.
Slightly relatively-yellow but setting highly suggestive of ice.
